links.explanation:
Placeholder: truck kilometres relate to GDP via an econometric relationship (needs calibration).

Grounded scaling assumption (NL defaults): treat this edge as a local linear sensitivity around baseline. Use link weight 0.5 to set sensitivity factor 0.275. With source scale≈2e+08 vkm/jaar and target scale≈464.39 € billion (NL), set β=0.275·(464.39/2e+08)=6.39e-07 so typical source changes produce moderate (order-of-magnitude) target changes without destabilising the dashboard.

links.formula: ΔN = ΔTRUCK_KM / 40.000 OF total cars on road (totaal jaar) = ΔTRUCK_KM / 40.000 + personal cars
links.explanation: Change in vehicles on road from change in freight vehicle-km, using an average annual vehicle-km per vehicle.

Exposure effect: more vehicles tends to increase accident count (placeholder).

Grounded scaling assumption (NL defaults): treat this edge as a local linear sensitivity around baseline. Use link weight 0.6 to set sensitivity factor 0.3. With source scale≈1 veh/day of vkm/jaar and target scale≈1 Traffic accidents per year, set β=0.3·(1/1)=0.3 so typical source changes produce moderate (order-of-magnitude) target changes without destabilising the dashboard.

links.explanation:
beta is 0.58 (β=−1.05+0.02972⋅55≈0.58) Sleep disturbance increases with noise; implement function later. Sleep disturbance due to noise is commonly modelled using a nonlinear exposure–response relationship. In this model, the WHO quadratic function
%High sleep disturbance = 20.8 − 1.05·dB + 0.01486·dB²
is approximated locally by a linear sensitivity (β) around the baseline noise level, allowing changes in noise to be propagated through the causal model.

Linearisation of WHO exposure–response: %HSD = 20.8 − 1.05·dB + 0.01486·dB². Around NL baseline ~55 dB (Lden), slope d(%)/d(dB)=−1.05+2·0.01486·55=0.58 %-points per dB. Use Δ(%HSD)≈β·Δ(dB).

vars.name: beta
vars.label: Effect size (beta)
vars.description: Linearisation of WHO exposure–response: %HSD = 20.8 − 1.05·dB + 0.01486·dB². Around NL baseline ~55 dB (Lden), slope d(%)/d(dB)=−1.05+2·0.01486·55=0.58 %-points per dB. Use Δ(%HSD)≈β·Δ(dB).

links.formula: Δ(Mental wellbeing problems) ≈ β · Δ(% poor sleep)
links.explanation:
beta = 0.0231.. Sleep problems associate with worse mental wellbeing (placeholder).

Mapping odds-style evidence to wellbeing index: reports like OR≈1.26 per +10pp poor sleep imply worse outcomes. To keep mental wellbeing as 0–100 index, assume +10pp sleep disturbance corresponds to ~−3 index points (conservative NL-scale), so β=3/10=0.3 index-points per %-point, with negative sign: ΔWellbeing≈−β·Δ(disturbance).

vars.name: beta
vars.label: Effect size (beta)
vars.description: Mapping odds-style evidence to wellbeing index: reports like OR≈1.26 per +10pp poor sleep imply worse outcomes. To keep mental wellbeing as 0–100 index, assume +10pp sleep disturbance corresponds to ~−3 index points (conservative NL-scale), so β=3/10=0.3 index-points per %-point, with negative sign: ΔWellbeing≈−β·Δ(disturbance).

links.explanation:
Placeholder: emissions correlate with air quality impacts depending on index definition.

Proxy assumption: GHG (Mt CO₂, WTW) tracks combustion. NL-scale: +10 Mt CO₂ change ≈ +0.1 µg/m³ PM2.5 (order-of-magnitude proxy), so β=0.1/10=0.01 µg/m³ per Mt CO₂. Model computation uses this simplified proxy linear mapping.

vars.name: beta
vars.label: Effect size (beta)
vars.description: Proxy assumption: GHG (Mt CO₂, WTW) tracks combustion. NL-scale: +10 Mt CO₂ change ≈ +0.1 µg/m³ PM2.5 (order-of-magnitude proxy), so β=0.1/10=0.01 µg/m³ per Mt CO₂.

links.explanation:
More green space improves air quality (placeholder).

Assumption (NL typical): +10 percentage-points % green within 300 m reduces PM2.5 by ~0.5 µg/m³ (urban greening co-benefit). Linearised as ΔPM2.5 ≈ −β·Δ(% green); β=0.5/10=0.05 µg/m³ per %-point. Model computation uses this simplified linear approximation.

vars.name: beta
vars.label: Effect size (beta)
vars.description: Assumption (NL typical): +10 percentage-points % green within 300 m reduces PM2.5 by ~0.5 µg/m³ (urban greening co-benefit). Linearised as ΔPM2.5 ≈ −β·Δ(% green); β=0.5/10=0.05 µg/m³ per %-point.

links.formula:
Δ(Green/Grey ratio) ≈ −β · Δ(Infrastructure land [ha]),
with β derived from (G − ΔP)/(R + ΔP) − (G/R) around the baseline
links.explanation:
An increase in infrastructure land typically reduces the Green/Grey ratio by converting green space into built (grey) area.
In this model, the effect is represented using a linear approximation: each additional hectare of infrastructure land leads to a proportional decrease in the Green/Grey ratio.
This relationship is a simplified, first-order approximation of the underlying ratio
(
G
−
Δ
P
)
/
(
R
+
Δ
P
)
(G−ΔP)/(R+ΔP) around the baseline situation.
It is intended to capture the direction and relative strength of the effect for scenario exploration, rather than to model exact land-use accounting or nonlinear dynamics.

links.formula: p_nieuw = 1,1*p/(1-p+1,1*p) met p (percentage non-compliance) en m (stress score 1,1)
links.explanation:
From spreadsheet (placeholder).

Grounded scaling assumption (NL defaults): treat this edge as a local linear sensitivity around baseline. Use link weight 0.5 to set sensitivity factor 0.123. With source scale≈1 PSS-10 and target scale≈100 %, set β=0.123·(100/1)=12.3 so typical source changes produce moderate (order-of-magnitude) target changes without destabilising the dashboard.
